title: Bass v. Isochem
description: In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, claimant was denied compensation by the Single Commissioner and the Appellate Panel for an alleged carpal tunnel syndrome injury.  The basis for the denial of compensation was the failure of the claimant to report an alleged injury in January 2001 until December 2001.  The Workersâ€™ Compensation Appellate Panel ruled that the claimant did not provide a reasonable excuse for her failure to give notice and the employer was prejudiced thereby.  The Circuit Court reversed, concluding that the order of the Appellate Panel was not supported by substantial evidence in the record.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Teresa A. Bass, Employee,
v.
Isochem and St. Paul Fire & Marine Insurance Co.,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3996
Heard May 11, 2005 â€“Filed June 6, 2005

Stanford E. Lacy, of Columbia, for Appellants.
David V. Benson, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, the employer, Isochem Colors, Inc., appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the denial of benefits to Teresa A. Bass by the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  The circuit court reversed on the ground that substantial evidence did not support the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision to deny benefits because Bass failed to give timely notice of her accident to Isochem.Â  We affirm in result and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In August of 1999, Bass was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  After her doctor prescribed Motrin, Bass â€œdidnâ€™t have the problem anymore.â€Â  On November 16, 2000, Bass began working at Isochem as a truck driver.Â  Prior to starting work at Isochem, Bass had a pre-employment physical and was â€œpronounced fit and able to work.â€Â  At Isochem, Bass was responsible for delivering large drums of powdered dye weighing between 100 to 500 pounds.Â  This required Bass to load and unload the drums by tilting them on their edge and rolling the drums off of the truck, arm over arm, as she made deliveries.Â  Depending on the number of delivery orders Isochem received, Bass delivered between one and fifty drums per day.
According to Bass, in January of 2001, she was delivering drums of dye to Amble Knitwear in Kings Mountain when she tipped a drum and â€œhad some pain in [her] hand.â€Â  Bass declared she â€œfirst notice[ed] problems with [her] arms when [she was] working for Isochem . . . [a]bout January of 2001.â€Â Â  Bass did not immediately inform anyone at work of her â€œproblemsâ€ because she â€œthought it would go away.â€Â  Bass stated she informed her supervisor, Angela Radcliff, of the â€œproblemsâ€ â€œa few months later.â€Â  Bass admitted she did not remember exactly when she told Radcliff but asserted that she advised Radcliff of her â€œproblemsâ€ â€œon a few occasions.â€Â  Bass testified:

I told [Radcliff] that moving the drums and all is bothering me.Â  The pain is bothering me.Â  I even told her that my hands were going numb at night.Â  I told her that my hands, as a matter of fact I was driving and my hands were going numb while I was driving.Â  And I was talking to her on the telephone at that time.Â  And I told her that my hands were going numb then.

Radcliff did not recall Bass mentioning any â€œproblems with her hands or wristsâ€ until November of 2001.Â  Radcliff professed: â€œ[Bass] had come to me and she had said that that night during when she was sleeping that they were going numb and they were, you know, felt like they were asleep.Â  And they were bothering her and hurting her.â€Â  In the Supervisorâ€™s Accident Investigation Report, Radcliff indicated Bassâ€™ â€œHand/Wristâ€ injury was reported on December 6, 2001.Â  Bridget Roberge filled out a â€œWorkersâ€™ Compensationâ€”First Report of Injury or Illnessâ€ form on December 6, 2001.Â  On the form, Roberge noted the â€œdate of injury/illnessâ€ and the â€œdate employer notifiedâ€ was â€œ12/06/01.â€Â  Roberge further noted the â€œtype of injury/illnessâ€ was â€œcarpal tunnel syndrome (CTS)â€ and the â€œpart of body affectedâ€ was the â€œwrist.â€
After several months of progressive pain, Bass sought medical treatment from Dr. Donald H. McQueen, III on November 28, 2001.Â  At Dr. McQueenâ€™s office, Bass answered questions on the â€œPatient Medical History Formâ€ in the following manner:

What will we be seeing you for today?Â  wristÂ Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  
. . . . 
  
If this was not the result of an accident, please tell us when your pain started.Â  If you are unsure, please give an approximate date:Â  approx. 10 mons. ago

In his medical note from Bassâ€™ November visit, Dr. McQueen wrote: â€œProblem: Pain in both hands with numbness. . . . Has developed pain in both hands.â€Â  Dr. McQueen diagnosed Bass with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome and suggested surgery to alleviate her symptoms.Â  Bass underwent a right carpal tunnel release on December 28, 2001 and a left carpal tunnel release on January 28, 2002.Â  In a letter to Bassâ€™ attorney dated January 15, 2002, Dr. McQueen opined:

[I] am unable to state that most probably and to a reasonable . . . degree of medical certainty that [Bassâ€™ work] activities have caused injury to her wrists.
. . . [A] person with carpal tunnel syndrome would most likely aggravate a pre-existing condition if they performed a strenuous job in a repetitious manner.
It is reasonable to say that Ms. Bass may have aggravated a pre-existing condition.

On January 9, 2002, Bass filed a Form 50 seeking Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits for bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  On the Form 50, Bass alleged:

1.a.Â  The claimant sustained an accidental injury to Both arms on 11-28-01 (12a says 12-6-01) in York County, State of South Carolina.
1.b.Â  Describe briefly how the accident occurredÂ  Repetitive loading and unloading of drums of powdered dye weighing From 110 through 400 lbs. caused injury to both wrists and arm manifesting itself in the need (See Attachment)
  
. . . .
  
4.Â  At the time of the injury the claimant was performing services arising out of and in the course of employment.
5.Â  Notice of the accidental injury was given to the employer on 11-28-01 in the following manner:Â  Angela, her supervisorâ€”on various occasions and on 11-28-01.

Isochem denied the claim on the ground that Bass failed to give timely notice.
In spite of the surgery, Bass continued to have problems.Â  Because of these â€œcomplications,â€ Bass was evaluated by Dr. J. Samuel Seastrunk, an orthopedic surgeon, on April 1, 2002.Â  When asked if she told Dr. Seastrunk â€œabout this event in January of 2001,â€ Bass replied: â€œYes, sir, I did.â€Â  Bass testified:

I told [Dr. Seastrunk] that I was at Amble Knitwear in Kings Mountain [in January of 2001] and I tipped a drum and I realized that I had some pain in my hand.Â  Then I told him that the pain got worser [sic] and worser [sic].Â  And I got to where I just couldnâ€™t stand it no more.Â  And I ended up going to Dr. McQueen and he done surgery.

Counsel for Isochem asked Bass: â€œIs it fair to say then that the pain you were having in your hands, was the first time that you related it to rolling the drums was in January of 2001?â€Â  Bass answered: â€œApproximately that time.â€
In his medical notes, Dr. Seastrunk stated: â€œ[Bass] relates that sometime in January of 2001 that she injured both wrists when she pulled on a drum and her wrists began hurting her.â€Â  Dr. Seastrunk opined:

  
    
      
        IMPRESSION: 
         1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome with bilateral carpal tunnel release as a result of Workers Comp injury from repetitive loading and unloading heavy weights.
      
    
  


DISPOSITION AND DISCUSSION:
From the information that I have and in accordance with my evaluation of Ms. Bass today, it is my feeling that the problems she is having with both wrists, that is carpal tunnel syndrome bilaterally, is directly related to the repetitive loading and unloading of drums which seem to be an ongoing process, necessitating her to refer herself to Dr. McQueen on 11-28-01 in which he made the diagnosis of bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome. . . . [I]t is my feeling that [Bass] is impaired to her right upper extremity by at least ten percent 10% as a result of the carpal tunnel syndrome and also to her left upper extremity by at least thirteen percent (13%) relative to the carpal tunnel syndrome and also the area of hard spot in her left palm.

In his deposition, Dr. Seastrunk said Bass described an injury to him that occurred in January of 2001:

She was describing these drums and she apparently was pulling on the drum.Â  I donâ€™t know exactly what these drums look like.Â  She probably used a hand dolly or something to maneuver these things and was pulling on a drum, probably trying to get it in better position and she had a feeling of pain, if I recall, in her wrist area. . . . The date of the injury she gives is January 2001.

Dr. Seastrunk reiterated: â€œMy opinion is that [Bass] developed carpal tunnel as a result of the type of activity she was doing.â€
The Single Commissioner denied Bassâ€™ claim for benefits.Â  In the Commissionerâ€™s order under â€œStatement of the Case,â€ the Commissioner declared: â€œThis is a denied carpal tunnel syndrome case.â€Â  Under â€œSummary of Evidence,â€ the Commissioner stated:

Bass has a history of carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  On August 31, 1999, she was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome by her family physician, Dr. Steven Oehme.Â  Bass denied any long-term affects [sic] and did not return to Dr. Oehme for follow-up visits.Â  Dr. Oehmeâ€™s report . . . states claimant was diagnosed with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, mild, left greater than the right.Â  Dr. Oehmeâ€™s report indicates Bass should take anti-inflammatories and consider a brace.Â  The report states that, â€œShe agrees.â€
  
. . . .
  
Bass underwent right carpal tunnel release by Dr. McQueen on December 28, 2001.Â  She underwent left carpal tunnel release on January 28, 2002. . . .

In the section entitled â€œFindings of Fact,â€ the Commissioner found: â€œOn August 11, 1999, claimant was first diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome by Dr. Oehme and was given anti-inflammatories.â€Â  The Commissioner noted that Bass testified her initial injury occurred in January 2001.Â  Under â€œConclusions of Law,â€ the Commissioner explained: â€œCarpal tunnel syndrome, even if caused by repetitive motion, is compensable as an accident under the Act.â€Â  The Commissioner concluded:

Claimant suffered an injury by accident in January 2001 but did not report it until December 6, 2001.Â  In the meantime, her condition became progressively worse such that ultimately it required a carpal tunnel release to both wrists.Â  Although claimant had frequent conversations with her supervisor, she did not report her injury until eleven months thereafter which is unreasonable.Â  The employer was prejudiced because it had no opportunity to provide medical treatment until claimantâ€™s condition had progressed to such an extent that surgery was required on both hands.Â  Claimant is in violation of Section 42-15-20.Â  Her claim is barred by her failure to give the requisite 90 days notice and her claim for benefits is denied.

The Appellate Panel unanimously affirmed the Single Commissioner and denied benefits to Bass.Â  The Panel expounded:

The Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law as established by the hearing commissioner are correct and . . . are adopted verbatim by the panel as though repeated herein.
Further, to support the hearing commissionerâ€™s decision, this panel notes:
The commissioner found in his order that the claimant did indeed suffer an injury by accident.Â  It was not compensable due to the claimantâ€™s failure to report and give notice as required by law.

ORDER

The order of the single commissioner is hereby affirmed.Â  All Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law are incorporated to become the final Decision and Order of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.

(emphasis in original).Â  In a footnote, the Panel stated that â€œ[a]ll unchanged Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law as contained in the single commissionerâ€™s order are specifically referenced and included in toto in the â€œorderâ€ portion of this decision.â€Â  (Emphasis in original).
The circuit court reversed the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision regarding compensability on the ground that substantial evidence did not support the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings.Â  The court ruled:

In her Form 50, Ms. Bass did place a single date of accident in January of 200[1].Â  She also, however, alleged that the repetitive loading and unloading of drums was the cause of her problems which resulted in the medical care and treatment of November 28, 2001.Â  The Full Commission and the hearing commissioner ignored that alternative pleading. . . .
. . . To deny [Bass] benefits based on one position in her Form 50 denies the whole purpose of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act which is to protect injured workers.
The opinion of this Court, therefore, is that the Full Commission and the hearing commissionerâ€™s Order is not supported by substantial evidence of record and should be reversed.Â  The medical records, particularly the testimony of Dr. Seastrunk coupled with Ms. Bassâ€™ testimony, clearly indicates that this was a repetitive motion injury deemed by our Supreme Court to be compensable.Â  The purpose of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is for inclusion of injured workers not exclusion.Â  Ms. Bass was injured in the course and scope of her employment and is entitled to benefits.

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (2005).
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs the standard of review in a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision.Â  Frame, 357 S.C. at 527, 593 S.E.2d at 494; Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Lockridge v. Santens of America, Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€).Â  Pursuant to the APA, this Courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  See Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 610 S.E.2d 488 (2005); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. # 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); see also Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 191, 603 S.E.2d 858, 859 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.â€); Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 434 S.E.2d 292 (Ct. App. 1993) (noting that in reviewing decision of Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, court of appeals will not set aside its findings unless they are not supported by substantial evidence or they are controlled by error of law).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004); Jones v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 586 S.E.2d 111 (2003); Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).
The Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729; Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate Panel.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000); Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999); DuRant v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 604 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin, 351 S.C. at 618, 571 S.E.2d at 95; Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591.Â  Where there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate Panel are conclusive.Â  Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d at 681.
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  It is not within our province to reverse findings of the Appellate Panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Pratt, 357 S.C. at 622, 594 S.E.2d at 274-75; Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Isochem argues the circuit court erred in reversing the Appellate Panelâ€™s denial of Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits to Bass.Â  Isochem alleges Bass suffered a single, identifiable injury by accident in January of 2001 and failed to give notice of her injury within ninety days of its occurrence, as required by section 42-15-20 of the South Carolina Code.Â  We disagree.
A priori, we are confronted with the novel issue arising from the factual scenario of this case: Is a repetitive trauma injury, i.e., carpal tunnel syndrome, treated separately and differently from an identifiable injury by accident under the notice mandate of section 42-15-20?
I.Â  Principles of Statutory Construction
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature.Â  Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 579 S.E.2d 334 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils., Inc., 362 S.C. 403, 406, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe primary purpose in construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 567 S.E.2d 240 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. School Dist. of Greenville County, 331 S.C. 19, 501 S.E.2d 725 (1998); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Municipal Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT&T Communications of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 606 S.E.2d 468 (2004); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582.Â  The courtâ€™s primary function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent of the General Assembly.Â  Smith v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 564 S.E.2d 358 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment based upon their own notions of public policy.â€Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
When a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its literal meaning.Â  Miller v. Aiken, Op. No. 25976 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 2, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 19 at 16); Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 442 S.E.2d 177 (1994).Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the rules of statutory construction and this Court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 454 S.E.2d 890 (1995); see also City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C. 556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it which are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.â€).Â  What a legislature says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative intent or will.Â  Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction.Â  Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d 465 (1998); Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 475 S.E.2d 762 (1996); Worsley Cos. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 567 S.E.2d 907 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. South Carolina Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970) (observing that where the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language).Â  Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.
If the language of an act gives rise to doubt or uncertainty as to legislative intent, the construing court may search for that intent beyond the borders of the act itself.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207; see also Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here a statute is ambiguous, the Court must construe the terms of the statute.â€).Â  An ambiguity in a statute should be resolved in favor of a just, beneficial, and equitable operation of the law.Â  Hudson, 336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at 582; Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 486 S.E.2d at 495; City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In construing a statute, the court looks to the language as a whole in light of its manifest purpose.Â  State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 573 S.E.2d 783 (2002); Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C. 213, 464 S.E.2d 109 (1995); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 560, 486 S.E.2d at 494.
A statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.Â  See Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 22, 579 S.E.2d at 336 (â€œA statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.â€).Â  The real purpose and intent of the lawmakers will prevail over the literal import of the words.Â  Browning v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 414 S.E.2d 115 (1992).
Courts will reject a statutory interpretation which would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C. 362, 529 S.E.2d 280 (2000); Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 440 S.E.2d 364 (1994).Â  A court should not consider a particular clause in a statute as being construed in isolation, but should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  See Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. at ___, 611 S.E.2d at 302; see also Mid-State Auto Auction v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 476 S.E.2d 690 (1996) (stating that in ascertaining the intent of the legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or provision but should consider the language of the statute as a whole).
II.Â  Notice Requirement/Section 42-15-20
The notice requirement, section 42-15-20 of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, reads:

Every injured employee or his representative shall immediately on the occurrence of an accident, or as soon thereafter as practicable, give or cause to be given to the employer a notice of the accident and the employee shall not be entitled to physicianâ€™s fees nor to any compensation which may have accrued under the terms of this Title prior to the giving of such notice, unless it can be shown that the employer, his agent or representative, had knowledge of the accident or that the party required to give such notice had been prevented from doing so by reason of physical or mental incapacity or the fraud or deceit of some third person.Â  No compensation shall be payable unless such notice is given within ninety days after the occurrence of the accident or death, unless reasonable excuse is made to the satisfaction of the Commission for not giving such notice and the Commission is satisfied that the employer has not been prejudiced thereby. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985) (emphasis added).
Section 42-15-20 requires that every injured employee or his representative give the employer notice of a job-related accident within ninety days after its occurrence.Â  Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 335 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985); see also McCraw v. Mary Black Hosp., 350 S.C. 229, 237, 565 S.E.2d 286, 290 (2002) (â€œPursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985), notice to the employer must be given within 90 days after the occurrence of the accident upon which the employee is basing her claim.â€).Â  Generally, the injury is not compensable unless notice is given within ninety days.Â  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The burden is upon the claimant to show compliance with the notice provisions of section 42-15-20.Â  See Lowe v. Am-Can Transport Servs., Inc., 283 S.C. 534, 324 S.E.2d 87 (Ct. App. 1984).
Section 42-15-20 provides no specific method of giving notice, the object being that the employer be actually put on notice of the injury so he can investigate it immediately after its occurrence and can furnish medical care for the employee in order to minimize the disability and his own liability.Â  See Teigue v. Appleton Co., 221 S.C. 52, 68 S.E.2d 878 (1952); Hanks, 286 S.C. at 381, 335 S.E.2d at 93.Â  While the notice requirement must be construed liberally in favor of claimants, it is â€œnot to be treated as a mere formality or technicality and dispensed with as a matter of course.â€Â  Mintz v. Fiske-Carter Constr. Co., 218 S.C. 409, 414, 63 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1951).Â  The purpose of section 42-15-20 is twofold: â€œfirst, it affords protection of the employer in order that he may investigate the facts and question witnesses while their memories are unfaded, and second, it affords the employer opportunity to furnish medical care of the employee in order to minimize the disability and consequent liability upon the employer.â€Â  Id.
This Court addressed the notice requirement in Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002):

The statutory efficacy of Â§ 42-15-20 is bifurcated: (1) affording protection for the employer to investigate the facts and circumstances of an accident or injury and to question witnesses while memories are fresh; and (2) permitting the employer the opportunity and privilege to provide medical treatment and care to minimize disability and concomitant liability of the employer.
We rule the language of Â§ 42-15-20 in regard to notice should be liberally construed in favor of claimants.Â  We conclude that notice is adequate, when there is some knowledge of accompanying facts connecting the injury or illness with the employment, and signifying to a reasonably conscientious supervisor that the case might involve a potential compensation claim.

Id. at 459, 562 S.E.2d at 683.
In his treatise on Workersâ€™ Compensation law, Professor Larson discussed the notice requirement:

Under most acts, there are two distinct limitations periods that must be observed: The period for notice of injury, and the period for claiming compensation.
Notice of injury, the first step in compensation procedure, is normally given to the employer. . . . The period is comparatively short; it may be â€œforthwith,â€ or â€œas soon as practicable,â€ or a specified period of a few weeks or months.Â  The purpose is dual: First, to enable the employer to provide immediate medical diagnosis and treatment with a view to minimizing the seriousness of the injury; and second, to facilitate the earliest possible investigation of the facts surrounding the injury.Â  If, upon receiving notice, the employer wishes to controvert the claim, it must itself file a notice to this effect.Â  Failure to do so, however, will not estop the employer from later asserting its defenses.

7 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 126.01 (2004).
Section 42-15-20 is a policy statement embedded in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act by the South Carolina General Assembly that consolidates and harmonizes the employer and employee under the statutory rubric of notification and accountability.
III.Â  Repetitive Trauma Injury
Generally, a repetitive trauma injury, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, is compensable under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Pee v. AVM, Inc., 352 S.C. 167, 573 S.E.2d 785 (2002).Â  The Pee court found â€œa repetitive trauma injury meets the definition of injury by accident in that it is an unforeseen injury caused by trauma.â€Â  Id. at 174, 573 S.E.2d at 789.
Repetitive trauma injuries have a gradual onset caused by the cumulative effect of repetitive traumatic events or â€œmini-accidents.â€Â  Schurlknight v. City of North Charleston, 352 S.C. 175, 574 S.E.2d 194 (2002).Â  It is difficult to determine the date an accident occurs in a repetitive trauma case because there is no definite time of injury.Â  Id.Â  â€œApplying the discovery rule to such an injury often works to the prejudice of an employee who discovers symptoms of a repetitive trauma injury but continues to work.â€Â  Id. at 178, 574 S.E.2d at 195.
In a repetitive trauma case, although the statute of limitations begins to run the last day of exposure, a Workersâ€™ Compensation claimant is still required to separately give the employer notice of an injury.Â  See Schurlknight, 352 S.C. at 178-79, 574 S.E.2d at 195-96 (citing Â§ 42-15-20) (â€œWe also note the separate requirement that a worker give the employer notice of an injury.â€).Â  This notice requirement ensures the employer will not be unfairly prejudiced by a two-year period for filing that begins from the last date of exposure.Â  Id.
IV.Â  Applicability of Section 42-15-20 to
Repetitive Trauma Injury/Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
A.Â  The Extant Evidentiary Record
Deciding this case on the basis of a specific â€œaccidentâ€ in January of 2001 is a misreckoning or inadvertency of the factual and legal record.Â  Encapsulated in the Single Commissionerâ€™s order, as affirmed by the Appellate Panel, is specific and definitive discussion and evaluation of the carpal tunnel syndrome experienced by Bass with precedential analysis beginning with Pee.Â  A failure by this Court to decide the novel issue of whether carpal tunnel syndrome as a repetitive trauma injury meets the statutory mandate of section 42-15-20 at the temporal occurrence of the disabling injury would be judicial dereliction.
B.Â  Analogy to Occupational Disease Cases
Section 42-15-20 applies in occupational disease cases.Â  In Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 335 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985), the court of appeals explicated:

The appellants argue that Hanks failed to comply with the statutory requirement that he give notice of his injury to his employer within ninety days after its occurrence.Â  They point out that if the injury occurred on June 28, 1979, the date Hanks was diagnosed as permanently and totally disabled, Hanks did not give them notice of his injury until December 3, 1980, the date he filed the claim.
  
. . . .
  
Section 42-15-20 requires that every injured employee or his representative give the employer notice of a job-related accident within ninety days after its occurrence.Â  Generally, the injury is not compensable if timely notice is not given.Â  In the case of occupational diseases, the â€œaccidentâ€ occurs when the employee becomes disabled and could, through reasonable diligence, discover that his condition is a compensable one.Â  Drake v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 241 S.C. 116, 127 S.E.2d 288 (1962).
Section 42-15-20 provides no specific method of giving notice, the object being that the employer be actually put on notice of the injury so he can investigate it immediately after its occurrence and can furnish medical care for the employee in order to minimize the disability and his own liability.Â  Teigue v. Appleton Co., 221 S.C. 52, 68 S.E.2d 878 (1952).

Id. at 381, 335 S.E.2d at 93 (emphasis added).Â  Thereafter, in Bailey v. Covil Corp., 291 S.C. 417, 354 S.E.2d 35 (1987), the supreme court held:

Employers also contend that Employee did not give timely notice of his claim.Â  An employee must give notice of an occupational disease claim within ninety days after the date he becomes disabled and could discover with reasonable diligence that his condition is compensable.Â  [White v. Orr-Lyons Mills, 287 S.C. 174, 336 S.E.2d 467 (1985); Drake v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 241 S.C. 116, 127 S.E.2d 288 (1962); Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 335 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985)]; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985).Â  The filing of the claim in this case within ninety days of the date of disability satisfied the requirement of timely notice.

Id. at 419, 354 S.E.2d at 36 (emphasis added).
In Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999), the court of appeals examined the notice requirement as it applies to a claimant with an occupational disease:

Bard avers the Circuit Court erred in refusing to reverse the Commissionâ€™s decision that Muir gave timely notice of his claim pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985).
Section 42-15-20 requires an injured employee to â€œimmediately on the occurrence of an accident, or as soon thereafter as practicable, give or cause to be given to the employer a notice of the accident.â€Â  Generally, the injury is not compensable unless notice is given within ninety days.Â  Id.Â  With an occupational disease, the â€œaccidentâ€ occurs when the employee becomes disabled and could, through reasonable diligence, discover that his condition is compensable.Â  Bailey v. Covil Corp., 291 S.C. 417, 354 S.E.2d 35 (1987); Hanks v. Blair Mills, Inc., 286 S.C. 378, 335 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  In occupational disease cases, compensability accrues at the time of death or disability.Â  See Glenn v. Columbia Silica Sand Co., 236 S.C. 13, 112 S.E.2d 711 (1960).
Bard argues Muir did not give timely notice of injury because he was not reasonable in discovering the nature of his medical problems.Â  It does not dispute Muirâ€™s testimony that he informed his superiors at Bard in the spring of 1992 of his diagnosis and belief that he had contracted the hepatitis through handling the catheters.
 Notice begins to run when the employee becomes disabled and could discover with reasonable diligence his condition is compensable.Â  Muir did not become disabled by his condition until August, 1992.Â  Therefore, Muir had actually given notice of the nature of his disease before he became disabled.

Id. at 295, 519 S.E.2d at 598 (emphasis added).
Professor Larson declared: â€œThe optimum rule in disease cases . . . is the dual type of rule worked out judicially in California: The period begins to run when the disease has culminated in disability and when by reasonable diligence the claimant could have discovered that the condition was a compensable one.â€Â  7 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 126.10[2] (2004).
C.Â  Other Jurisdictions
Our research leads to the ineluctable conclusion that the efficacy of section 42-15-20 has never been analyzed in regard to a repetitive trauma injury, i.e., carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  No South Carolina case has addressed this precise question.Â  We commence our unprecedented and neoteric juridical journey in facing this novel issue by visiting other jurisdictions for edification and enlightenment.Â  When there is no case on point in South Carolina, our courts may look to other states to determine if the issue has been decided and if the decision is persuasive authority.Â  See Williams v. Morris, 320 S.C. 196, 464 S.E.2d 97 (1995); Silva v. Silva, 333 S.C. 387, 509 S.E.2d 483 (Ct. App. 1998); Golini v. Bolton, 326 S.C. 333, 482 S.E.2d 784 (Ct. App. 1997).
The Supreme Court of Tennessee, in Lawson v. Lear Seating Corp., 944 S.W.2d 340 (Tenn. 1997), ruled that, in gradual onset injuries like carpal tunnel syndrome, the date of the accident is the date on which the injury prevents the employee from working.Â  Id. at 343; see also Central Motor Express, Inc. v. Burney, 377 S.W.2d 947 (Tenn. 1964) (noting that the beginning date for computing notice to the employer in a gradual injury case is the date on which the disability manifests itself to such an extent that employee was forced to leave work).
When faced with this issue, the Court of Appeals of Kentucky concluded that â€œin cases where the injury is the result of many mini-traumas, the date for giving notice and the date for clocking a statute of limitations begins when the disabling reality of the injuries becomes manifest.â€Â  Randall Co. v. Pendland, 770 S.W.2d 687, 688 (Ky. Ct. App. 1989).Â  The Supreme Court of Kentucky announced:

[T]he notice and limitations provisions for a gradual injury are triggered when the worker becomes aware of a gradual injury and knows that it was caused by work, regardless of whether the symptoms that led to discovery of the injury later subside.Â  This approach is consistent with one of the purposes of the notice requirement, to enable the employer to take measures to minimize the workerâ€™s ultimate impairment and, hence, its liability.

Holbrook v. Lexmark Intâ€™l Group, Inc., 65 S.W.3d 908, 911 (Ky. 2002).Â  Recently, the Supreme Court of Kentucky reiterated:

A gradual injury generally arises imperceptibly, from the physical strain of numerous instances of minor workplace trauma, also referred to as minitrauma.Â  For that reason, the courts have applied a rule of discovery for establishing the date of injury.Â  Hence, a gradual injury becomes manifest for the purpose of notice and limitations with the workerâ€™s knowledge of the harmful change and the fact that it is caused by the work.

Brummitt v. Southeastern Kentucky Rehab. Indus., 156 S.W.3d 276 (Ky. 2005).
In International Paper Co. v. Melton, 866 So. 2d 1158 (Ala. Civ. App. 2003), the trial court found: â€œRegarding the notice issue of [Meltonâ€™s] carpal tunnel claim, the courts have held that the date of injury for cumulative trauma disorders such as carpal tunnel syndrome is the date of last exposure to the injurious job stimulation.â€Â  Affirming the trial court, the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama stated:

Moreover, in Zeanah v. Stewart Animal Clinic, P.C., 752 So. 2d 505, 508 (Ala. Civ. App. 1999), this court relied upon Dun & Bradstreet [Corp. v. Jones, 678 So. 2d 181 (Ala. Civ. App. 1996),] in concluding that, for purposes of the notice requirements under Â§ 25-5-78, â€œ[f]or accidents or occurrences involving cumulative-stress disorders, the date of the workerâ€™s last exposure to the stressor is considered the date of the injury.â€
. . . Based on the facts of this case and our holding in Zeanah, supra, we conclude that the trial court did not err in finding that Melton gave International Paper adequate and proper notice of his carpal tunnel syndrome claim.

Id. at 1162-63.
The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, in City of Philadelphia v. Workersâ€™ Comp. Appeal Bd., 851 A.2d 838 (Pa. 2004), explained:

[T]he question is a legal one concerning when the 120-day notice period in Section 311 begins to run in the case of an aggravation/ cumulative trauma injury, where the claimant suffers daily aggravation of her diagnosed condition, which becomes disabling only on her last day of employment.Â  This is a question of statutory construction . . . .
  
. . . .
  
. . . [I]n fixing the date of the occurrence of such an aggravation injury [carpel tunnel syndrome], it is apparent that the Commonwealth Court cases recognizing the distinct nature of such injuries are correct.Â  Thus, where as here the credited medical evidence establishes that a cumulative trauma disorder was at issue, and that conditions at work cause [a daily] aggravation of the disorder, notice must be deemed timely so long as it was given within 120 days of the last aggravation injuryâ€”which will usually be the last day at work or the day where total disability resulted.

Id. at 843, 847-48.
The Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma inculcated: â€œ[A] cumulative trauma injury is a single injury for purposes of notice and limitations.Â  The date of last exposure applies.â€Â  Fabsco Shell & Tube v. Eubank, 84 P.3d 792, 796 (Okla. Civ. App. 2003) (citations omitted).
The Court of Appeals of Iowa, in Venenga v. John Deere Component Works, 498 N.W.2d 422 (Iowa Ct. App. 1993), articulated:

Iowa adopted the cumulative injury rule in McKeever Custom Cabinets v. Smith, 379 N.W.2d 368, 374 (Iowa 1985).Â  In McKeever, the court also addressed the question of when a cumulative injury occurs for reporting and time limitation purposes: when pain prevents the employee from continuing to work, or when the pain occasions the need for medical attention.Â  Id.Â  The court adopted the rule finding an employee is disabled and injured when, because of pain or physical inability, he or she can no longer work.Â  Id.

Id. at 424.
The Supreme Court of Montana reviewed the notice requirement:

We conclude that claimant satisfied the notice requirement. Since claimantâ€™s disability was the result of cumulative traumas which occurred over a period of time, the date of injury, for purposes of complying with the notice requirement, is the date on which claimant was first unable to continue with his employment due to his physical condition.

Bodily v. John Jump Trucking, Inc., 819 P.2d 1262, 1267-68 (Mont. 1991).
In contradistinction to a time-dated accident, this evidentiary record posits a magnitudinous presentation of a carpal tunnel syndrome accidental injury.Â  Bassâ€™ testimony and the testimony of Dr. McQueen and Dr. Seastrunk support Bassâ€™ contention that her arms gradually worsened over time to the extent that she needed medical treatment and was disabled.
CONCLUSION
We rule that in applying section 42-15-20 to a repetitive trauma injury, i.e., carpal tunnel syndrome, the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission shall determine the statutory notice requirement from the time of disablement of the claimant.Â  Notice begins to run when the employee becomes disabled and could discover with reasonable diligence his condition is compensable.
Analyzing the efficacy of section 42-15-20 in regard to the injury suffered and sustained by Bass, we agree with the circuit judge that Bass did not sustain a single, identifiable injury by accident in January of 2001.Â  There is NO substantial evidence in the record to support a factual finding that Bass suffered and sustained a single, identifiable injury by accident in January of 2001.Â  The only evidence in the record is that Bass suffered and sustained a repetitive trauma injury, carpal tunnel syndrome, over a period of time resulting in disability in November of 2001.
We remand to the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission to make findings of fact and conclusions of law consistent with the adoption of our holding concerning the efficacy of section 42-15-20 in a repetitive trauma injury scenario.
Based on the foregoing, we AFFIRM IN RESULT and REMAND.
 STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

title: Floyd v. Floyd
description: In this civil appeal, appellants contend the trial court abused its discretion in finding Laurens W. Floyd, Jr. in contempt of its orders and requiring him to pay sanctions including legal expenses of the Respondent.  Further, appellants aver the trial court erred in admitting certain letters into evidence in violation of the hearsay rule and the attorney-client privilege.  Finally, appellants allege that the trial court erred in removing Laurens W. Floyd, Jr. as trustee of the charitable remainder trust.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Anne H. Floyd,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Laurens W. Floyd, Jr., individually and as Trustee of the Laurens Floyd Trust and the Charitable Remainder Trust of Laurens W. Floyd and Anne H. Floyd; Daniel D. Bozard as co-trustee of the Laurens Floyd Trust and the Charitable Remainder Trust of Laurens W. Floyd and Anne H. Floyd; Julia M. Floyd; and Robert H. Floyd, Individually, of whom Laurens Floyd, Jr., individually and as Trustee of the Laurens Floyd Trust and the Charitable Remainder Trust of Laurens W. Floyd and Anne H. Floyd; Daniel Bozard as co-trustee of the Laurens Floyd Trust and the Charitable Remainder Trust of Laurens W. Floyd are the,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3997
Submitted May 18, 2005 â€“ Filed June 13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
M. M. Weinberg, Jr., of Sumter, for Appellants.
Clarke W. DuBose, and Sarah P. Spruill, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Laurens Floyd, Jr. (Laurens) appeals a trial judgeâ€™s order awarding Anne Floyd (Anne) approximately $40,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and removing him as trustee of a charitable remainder trust.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 1, 1999, Laurens W. Floyd, Sr. (Floyd Sr.) executed an amended and restated trust agreement establishing several trusts, including Trust A for the benefit of his wife, Anne.Â  Trust A is a qualified terminable interest property trust, known as a Q-Tip trust.Â  According to the trust agreement, Floyd Sr.â€™s houses and lots in Pawleyâ€™s Island, South Carolina and his stock in the Dillon Provision Company, Inc. (or the proceeds from the sale of such stock) were to fund Trust A.Â  Trust A was to be administered as follows: 

1. Commencing with the date of the Settlorâ€™s death, the Trustee shall pay to or for the benefit of the Settlorâ€™s wife, Anne H. Floyd, all of the net income from Trust A in convenient installments, but not less frequently than quarter-annually.Â  Any accrued and undistributed income at the death of the Settlorâ€™s wife shall be paid to her personal representatives and administrators. 
2. In addition, the Trustee may pay to or apply for the benefit of the Settlorâ€™s wife such sums from the principal of Trust A as in the Trusteeâ€™s sole discretion shall be necessary or advisable from time to time for the medical care, education, support and maintenance in reasonable comfort of the Settlorâ€™s wife, taking into consideration to the extent the Trustee deems advisable any other income or resources of the Settlorâ€™s wife known to the Trustee. 

The trust agreement directed the remainder interest go to Floyd Sr.â€™s children upon Anneâ€™s death.Â Â  
Floyd Sr. was the original trustee of the trusts.Â  Floyd Sr.â€™s son, Laurens, and his (Floyd Sr.â€™s) business associate, Bozard, were nominated to serve as co-trustees upon his death.Â  In addition, the trust agreement provided upon the death or resignation of both Laurens and Bozard, First Citizen Bank and Trust Company of South Carolina (First Citizenâ€™s) was to serve as trustee.Â Â  
Floyd Sr. created a separate charitable remainder trust, under which Anne was a lifetime income beneficiary, with the remainder interest passing to several charities.Â  The charitable remainder trust document is not part of the record on appeal.Â  However, it appears from the pleadings, correspondence, and trial testimony that the trust was established March 13, 1996.Â  As the lifetime beneficiary, Anne was to receive 8% of the value of the trust each year.Â  Although the case caption suggests otherwise, Bozard did not serve with Laurens as trustee for the charitable remainder trust.Â  Laurens was the sole trustee.Â  
In February 2000, Floyd Sr. died, and Laurens and Bozard began serving as trustees of Trust A.Â  Trust A was funded with the two Pawleyâ€™s Island homes and the Dillon Provision Company stock.Â  Anne began residing in one of the Pawleyâ€™s Island homes.Â  The trust rented the other home for $400 per month.Â  
Approximately a year after Floyd Sr.â€™s death, Laurens sent a letter to Anne, his stepmother, explaining the administration of Trust A.Â  Laurens wrote:

Dear Anne:
. . . . 
To facilitate the handling of the trust assets, a money market account will be opened with Edward Jones.Â  The income from the assets, currently rent from the rental house, will be deposited into this account.Â  On a quarterly basis, we will issue you a check of the accrued income from the QTIP Trust.Â  Expenses incurred by the real property of the trust such as property taxes; property casulty [sic], liability, and flood insurance; upkeep and maintenance, etc., you will then be expected to pay for.Â  Any of the above expenses which exceed the income generated by the assets of the QTIP trust are, according to the terms of the QTIP Trust, your personal responsibility.

Anne disagreed with Laurensâ€™ interpretation of the trust agreement and sought assistance from attorney Donnie Dial.Â  Dial wrote letters to Charles Curry, the attorney for Floydâ€™s estate, asserting the trust was responsible for expenses relating to trust property.Â  Anne and Laurens engaged in several disagreements as to who was responsible for payment of various expenses related to the trust properties, including repairs to the roof of the rental house, replacement of the heat pump in Anneâ€™s house, payment of flood insurance and general property insurance, and payment of property taxes.Â  Laurens took the position that the trust was not responsible for the payment of these expenses.Â Â  Â 
In October 2001, Anne brought an action in probate court against Laurens and Bozard individually and as co-trustees.Â  Anne sought an accounting of both Trust A and the charitable remainder trust, and a declaratory judgment requiring the trustees to (1) repay any advances Anne paid on behalf of Trust A, (2) reinstate flood insurance on the properties, and (3) sell the Dillon Provision Company stock and reinvest the proceeds.Â  In addition, Anne petitioned for the removal of Laurens and Bozard as co-trustees of Trust A and Laurens as trustee of the charitable remainder trust.Â  
The case was removed to the circuit court.Â  The trial judge issued an interim order, which stated: 

[C]ounsel for petitioner brought to the Courtâ€™s attention that the trustees are failing to pay expenses of the Trust, including but not limited to real property taxes, flood insurance, and capital improvements such as a new roof for the rental house owned by the Trust and a new heat pump for the home owned by the Trust and occupied by Mrs. Floyd. 

Although he was not prepared to rule on the interpretation of the trust provisions, the trial judge indicated his concern about the preservation of the trust property.Â  Thus, he ordered: 

[T]he Trust shall pay for all costs of upkeep, repair, and protection of the Trust assets, including but not limited to the taxes, insurance, repairs, and upkeep on the two Pawleyâ€™s Island houses, and that such expenses are to be paid by the trustees first out of Trust income and then, if necessary, out of Trust principal.

After the trial judge issued this order, First Citizenâ€™s filed a motion to intervene as an interested party, which was granted.[2]Â  
Subsequently, Anne filed a motion for a rule to show cause based on the trusteesâ€™ failure to comply with the trial judgeâ€™s interim order.Â  Anne argued the trust failed to pay for the installation of a new heat pump in the house in which she resides, as required by the interim order.Â  The trial judge held a hearing on this motion, found Laurens in contempt of court, and ordered him to pay attorneyâ€™s fees incurred by Anne in enforcing the order.Â  In addition, the trial judge addressed Laurensâ€™ argument that the trust was not responsible for the payment of the heat pump because of the provision in the trust agreement giving the trustee the discretionary power to invade the trust principal.Â  The trial judge determined that provision did not pertain to the expenditures for maintenance of trust property.Â  After this order, the trial judge issued another order reflecting Laurensâ€™ and Bozardâ€™s decisions to voluntarily withdraw as trustees of Trust A.Â  
Ultimately, the trial judge held a hearing on the merits of Anneâ€™s complaint.Â  At the hearing, Laurens objected to the admission of several letters written by Dial on behalf of Anne and letters authored by Curry.Â  Laurens argued all of the letters were written by out-of-court declarants and, therefore, constituted inadmissible hearsay.Â  In addition, he maintained the letters from Curry to Laurens were protected by the attorney-client privilege and thus were not admissible.Â  The trial judge did not rule on the admissibility of the letters, but asked the parties to submit briefs supporting their positions.Â  After the parties submitted their briefs, the trial judge ruled the Dial letters were not admitted to show the truth of the matter asserted, but â€œto show that the co-trustees were placed on notice as to [Anneâ€™s] position and to show her efforts to resolve this matter without litigation.â€Â  The judge noted Dialâ€™s opinions contained in the letters were cumulative because the court already had interpreted the trust as requiring the trustees to protect the trust property.Â  Additionally, the trial judge found the letters written by Curry to Laurens were not privileged because â€œthe advice of an attorney to the trustee is not privileged from the trust beneficiaries.â€Â  Furthermore, the trial judge stated Laurens waived the privilege by producing the letters in discovery, and opened the door to admission of the letters by claiming he followed the advice of counsel.Â  
The trial judge issued a final order finding Laurens acted in bad faith and breached his fiduciary duties to Anne by (1) failing to pay the expenses of Trust A, (2) not making timely distributions of Trust A income to Anne, (3) neglecting to provide Anne an accounting of both trusts, (4) misstating the terms of Trust A, (5) managing Trust A property solely for the benefit of the remainder beneficiaries, (6) not following the advice of counsel as to his duties as a trustee, and (7) failing to follow court orders.Â  Based on these findings, Laurens was held personally liable for $40,347.21 of Anneâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and $22,331.60 of First Citizenâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In making this determination, the trial judge stated:Â  â€œthe assessment of fees and costs against Floyd, Jr. as herein specified, is not an award of attorneysâ€™ fees, per se, but rather an assessment of sanctions against Floyd, Jr. for his contempt of court, together with an award of damages to Wife and Bank for his breach of fiduciary duty.â€Â  Further, the trial judge removed Laurens as trustee of the charitable remainder trust, explaining, â€œWhile Floyd, Jr.â€™s actions in this case were not dishonest, they strongly support his removal as trustee from any trust affecting Wife.â€Â  
I.Â  Contempt and Sanctions
Laurens argues the trial judge erred in finding him in contempt.Â  He asserts because all income from the trust must be paid to Anne, the trust did not have funds to pay for expenses related to the trust property. Â Therefore, he contends an invasion of the trust principal would be necessary to pay those expenses.Â  Relying on the provision of the trust granting the trustee discretion to invade the principal for Anneâ€™s benefit, Laurens argues he properly exercised his discretion and chose not to invade the principal.Â  Laurens maintains the trial judge abused his discretion in holding him in contempt for failure to pay for replacement of the heat pump in the home in which Anne resides.Â  According to Laurens, the trial judgeâ€™s order was unlawful and he was not required to obey that order. 
Additionally, Laurens argues that even if the court did not err in holding him in contempt, the sanctions imposed were so disproportionate to the contempt as to constitute reversible error.Â  
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Standard of Review
A decision on contempt rests within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Fagan v. Timmons, 224 S.C. 286, 78 S.E.2d 628 (1953); Tirado v. Tirado, 339 S.C. 649, 530 S.E.2d 128 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œOn appeal, a decision regarding contempt should be reversed only if it is without evidentiary support or the trial judge has abused his discretion.â€Â  Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 840, 840 (1988) (citing Means v. Means, 277 S.C. 428, 288 S.E.2d 811 (1982); Fagan v. Timmons, 224 S.C. 286, 78 S.E.2d 628 (1953)); see also Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 120, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œA determination of contempt is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, but his discretion will be reversed when the finding is without evidentiary support or there is an abuse of discretion.â€).Â  â€œA determination of contempt is a serious matter and should be imposed sparingly; whether it is or is not imposed is within the discretion of the trial judge, which will not be disturbed on appeal unless it is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Haselwood v. Sullivan, 283 S.C. 29, 32-33, 320 S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing Hicks v. Hicks, 280 S.C. 378, 312 S.E.2d 598 (Ct. App. 1984)).
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Law/Analysis

 1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Law of the Case 

The finding of contempt and the award of fees are the law of the case.Â  First, a finding of contempt is immediately appealable regardless of whether damages have been determined.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 291, 513 S.E.2d 358, 364 (1999); Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 297, 609 S.E.2d 821, 837 (Ct. App. 2005); Jarrell v. Petoseed Co., 331 S.C. 207, 208, 500 S.E.2d 793, 793 (Ct. Initially, we reject Laurensâ€™ claims of innocence as to the charitable remainder trust.Â  He neglected to provide Anne with an accounting and violated a court order.Â  Indeed, in Crayton, the trusteeâ€™s negligence did not require his removal, but the court did order him to enter a $7,500 bond.Â  The court â€œfurther ordered that if [the trustee] fails to execute and file the bond above required within the time mentioned, or fails to do or perform any of the other matters and things required of him in this decree, then and in such event the said [trustee] is hereby removed as trustee of said trust estate[.]â€ Crayton, 140 S.C. at 521, 139 S.E. at 162. Thus Crayton firmly supports the removal of a trustee who violates a court order related to the trust.Â  
Furthermore, were we to find Laurens innocent of wrongdoing as to the charitable remainder trust, which we do not, we reject his argument that wrongdoing as trustee of Trust A has no bearing on the question of his removal as trustee of another trust where the trusts share a beneficiary.Â  Laurensâ€™ misconduct as trustee of Trust A is relevant to whether he should continue as trustee of the charitable remainder trust where the trusts share a common beneficiary.Â  Because Laurens has demonstrated his inability to honor his fiduciary duties and properly administer Trust A, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that Laurens is unfit to be trusted with the administration of the charitable remainder trust of which Anne is likewise a beneficiary.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s removal of Laurens as trustee of the charitable remainder trust.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Because Laurens did not appeal the trial judgeâ€™s order finding him in contempt of court, we find this decision to be the law of the case.Â  Regardless, the contempt finding was a proper exercise of the courtâ€™s discretion.Â  We affirm award of fees as a combination of sanctions and damages.Â  Further, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit into evidence letters written by Dial and Curry.Â  The letters are not hearsay, and they are not protected by the attorney-client privilege.Â  Finally, the trial judge did not err in his decision to remove Laurens as trustee of the charitable remainder trust.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED. 
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] First Citizenâ€™s Bank and Laurens entered into a settlement agreement during the pendency of this appeal resolving all matters between them.Â  Therefore, First Citizenâ€™s Bank is not a party to this appeal.Â
