THE STATE OF SOUTH
CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The
        State,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Michael Patrick Munyon,       
        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4003
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 20, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James Arthur Brown, Jr., of
        Beaufort, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D.
        McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
        Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney
        General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E.
        Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:  Michael
Munyon appeals the enhancement of his sentence for conspiracy to traffic
marijuana based on a prior drug-related offense.  We affirm.
FACTS
On April 8, 2003, the South Carolina
State Grand Jury indicted Michael Munyon for conspiracy to traffic one hundred
pounds or more of marijuana.  On October 7, 2003, Munyon appeared before
the circuit court and pled guilty to the lesser included offense of conspiracy
to traffic between ten and one hundred pounds of marijuana.  The trial
court treated the charge as his second offense.
Munyonâ€™s prior conviction arose
from a June 16, 2001, search of his Charleston
home.  Munyon and four others were charged with possession with intent to
distribute marijuana and possession with intent to distribute within one-half
mile of a school.  In March 2002, Munyon pled guilty to simple possession
and received a one hundred dollar fine.  
The charge for which Munyon was
indicted on April 8, 2003, concerns Munyonâ€™s involvement, beginning in 2002,
in a conspiracy to receive and sell large amounts of marijuana.  The
indictment mentions that the conspiracy began in November, 1999 and continued
until the time the indictment was issued.  Munyon argued the prior
conviction should not be treated as such for sentencing purposes because the
simple possession conviction was the result of a larger pattern of behavior
which ultimately resulted in the 2003 conspiracy charge.  The trial court
disagreed and sentenced Munyon to a mandatory minimum of five years and imposed
a fifteen thousand dollar fine. 
LAW AND DISCUSSION
Munyon argues that because the 2002
and 2003 convictions are related and arise from a single incident, the 2002
conviction should not be treated as a prior conviction for sentencing
purposes.  We disagree.
Munyon pled guilty to conspiracy to
traffic between ten and one hundred pounds of marijuana.  Section
44-53-370(e)(1)(a) of the South Carolina Code (2002) discusses the penalty for
this offense.  An individual convicted of a first offense must be sentenced
to at least one year, but not more than ten years and fined ten thousand
dollars.  Id.  If it is a second offense, the individual must be
sentenced to at least five years, but no more than twenty years and fined
fifteen thousand dollars.  Id.
Section 44-53-470 of the South
Carolina Code (2002) explains when a crime is considered a second or subsequent
offense.  It provides, â€œ[a]n offense is considered a second or subsequent
offense, if, prior to his conviction of the offense, the offender has at any
time been convicted under this article or under any State or Federal statute
relating to narcotic drugs, marihuana, depressant, stimulant, or hallucinogenic
drugs.â€ 
Because Munyon has a prior simple
possession of marijuana conviction from 2002, the plain terms of section
44-53-470 suggest the penalty for his current offense should be enhanced. 
Nevertheless, in State v. Boyd, 288 S.C. 206, 341 S.E.2d 144 (Ct. App.
1986), we explained that a court is restricted from using a prior conviction for
enhancement if the prior offense arose â€œout of simultaneous acts committed in
the course of a single incident.â€  Id.
at 209-10, 341 S.E.2d at 146.  In Boyd, the defendant was convicted
of a drug charge and sentenced as a third time offender.  Id. at 207, 341 S.E.2d at 145.  His sentence was enhanced
based on earlier convictions for possession of marijuana, hashish, and
prescription pills.  Id. 
However, the earlier convictions arose from the same arrest.  Id.  The court found Boyd should have been sentenced as a
second time offender because multiple convictions will be considered as one for
sentencing purposes if they â€œaris[e] out of simultaneous acts committed in the
course of a single incident.â€  Id. at 209-10, 341 S.E.2d at 146.  See also
State v. Woody, 345 S.C. 34, 545 S.E.2d 521 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding
armed robberies of a convenience store and the convenience store clerk were
committed within one incident and should only be treated as one conviction for
sentencing purposes).
Munyon argues the 2002 and 2003
convictions should be treated as one for sentencing purposes because they took
place in the same general location (Charleston), involved the same people, took
place during overlapping time frames, and involved similar crimes (dealing
marijuana).  However, Munyonâ€™s prior charge was based on possession with
intent to distribute on June 17, 2001.  By Munyonâ€™s own admission, he did
not enter the conspiracy that began in 1999 until 2002.  Therefore, the
charges did not arise out of simultaneous acts committed in the course of a
single incident. 
AFFIRMED.[1]
ANDERSON and STILWELL, JJ.,
concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215,
SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Historic Charleston Holdings, LLC, Respondent,
v.
Gerard Mallon, Dixie Holdings, LLC, and Dixie Developers, LLC,
Defendants,
Of whom Gerard Mallon is the, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 4004
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed June 27, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART,
REVERSED IN PART
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Deborah Harrison Sheffield, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Charles P. Summerall, IV, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J:Â  Gerard Mallon appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order awarding Historic Charleston Holdings, LLC, one-half of the proceeds from the sale of a piece of property owned by Dixie Holdings, LLC, of which both Mallon and Historic Charleston Holdings were members.Â  Additionally, Mallon appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s refusal to conduct an accounting, as well as the award of prejudgment interest, attorneyâ€™s fees, and costs to Historic Charleston Holdings.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
In June of 1998, Gerard Mallon formed Dixie Holdings, LLC, a member-managed, term limited liability company.Â  Mallon, William Storen,[1] and Historic Charleston Holdings, LLC (HCH) executed an operating agreement as the three members of Dixie Holdings.Â  Priestly Coker and Cynthia Coker were the sole members of HCH.[2]Â  Subsequently, HCH and Mallon also became members in Dixie Developers, LLC.Â  However, HCH ultimately sold its interest to Mallon, leaving Mallon as the sole member of Dixie Developers.Â  
The members formed Dixie Holdings for the purpose of purchasing, renovating, and selling various real properties.Â  Although Dixie Holdingsâ€™ operating agreement did not specify each memberâ€™s duties, the record indicates Priestly Coker (Coker) performed accounting and financial related services,[3] Mallon, through his construction company, renovated the properties, and Storen acted as the real estate agent in locating potential investment properties and later marketing them.Â Â  
Shortly after the execution of the operating agreement, Mallon, Storen, and Coker on behalf of HCH, amended the operating agreement to reflect the membersâ€™ interest in Dixie Holdings.Â  This amendment stated Mallon and HCH each owned a 49.5% interest and Storen owned a 1% interest.Â Â  
Dixie Holdings purchased four properties located in Charleston, South Carolina.Â  According to Mallon, a dispute arose between Mallon and Coker after Dixie Holdings sold two of those properties because Coker failed to provide financial information related to Dixie Holdings and Dixie Developers.Â  Although Mallon had been given money from the proceeds of those sales, he believed he had not separately been compensated for work performed in renovating those properties.Â  
In December 1999, the parties executed a written agreement in connection with a membersâ€™ meeting that took place several days prior.Â  The agreement provided for an audit of Dixie Holdings and stated if the members could not resolve their differences, then an arbitrator would be appointed by agreement of the parties.Â  In addition, the agreement stated, in pertinent part: 

The primary function of the formation of these companies is purchase and sale of Real Estate.
Sales are to be made while these matters are being dealt with.
The sales proceeds can be held in an escrow account.Â  OR [othen [sic] written accepted offer]. 

Coker gave Mallon a box containing some of the companyâ€™s financial records in April 2000.Â  
After the execution of this agreement, Dixie Holdings sold the third property, referred to by the parties as â€œ15 Felix Street,â€ on April 14, 2000.Â  Coker testified that, pursuant to the partiesâ€™ December 1999 agreement, he believed the net proceeds from the sale were to be placed in an escrow account until the parties determined what expenses needed to be paid and Mallon had been compensated for any related expenses.Â  The net proceeds of $41,845.30 were given to Mallon, who placed them in a bank account in the name of Dixie Developers,[4] of which he had sole signatory authority.Â  Despite requests from Coker within days of the closing that Mallon place the funds in a proper escrow account, Mallon retained the funds in the separate account and maintained sole signatory authority.Â  As a result, HCH, individually and in a derivative capacity as a member of Dixie Holdings, brought suit against Mallon, Dixie Holdings, and Dixie Developers[5] on October 11, 2002.[6]Â  
In its complaint, HCH alleged five causes of action.Â  HCH requested:Â  (1) a judicial decree winding up and dissolving Dixie Holdings; (2) a full and complete accounting of Dixie Holdings including transfers between it and Dixie Developers and Mallon; (3) injunctive relief reversing Mallonâ€™s diversion of funds and restraining Mallon from taking any action that would damage either HCH or Dixie Holdingsâ€™ interests; (4) a declaratory judgment regarding each memberâ€™s rights pursuant to section 15-53-10 of the South Carolina Code; and (5) attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to section 33-44-1104 of the South Carolina Code.Â  In addition to these causes of action, HCH requested the court award â€œfull relief under Section 33-44-801, an accounting, declaratory relief, injunctive relief, fair distribution, attorneyâ€™s fees, pre-judgment interest, costs, and such other relief as the Court may deem appropriate.â€Â  
After the circuit court referred the case to a master-in-equity, Mallon submitted an answer.Â  In his answer, Mallon asserted â€œan accounting is appropriate for both parties, and that Coker, who acted as the financial officer of Dixie [Holdings] has repeatedly and improperly failed to prepare a proper accounting, which should now be done.â€Â  Mallon also claimed entitlement to reimbursement for services he performed on various properties of Dixie Holdings that exceeded the proceeds Dixie Holdings received from the sale of 15 Felix Street.Â Â  
Immediately prior to trial, the master heard several motions in limine submitted by HCH.Â  In one motion, HCH requested the exclusion of any documents not submitted prior to November 21, 2003, when the parties exchanged discovery.Â  The master granted HCHâ€™s request.Â  Mallon did not object to the masterâ€™s decision.Â  
The master proceeded with a trial on the issues raised by the parties.Â  At trial, Mallon presented a statement of charges in which he claimed he was owed $9,280 for work performed on four Felix Street properties, including $1,900 for work performed on 15 Felix Street.Â  In his order, the master denied Mallonâ€™s request for an accounting concluding he had â€œnot timely requested, and waived, any right to an accounting.â€Â  The master also determined Mallon was not entitled to reimbursement for any alleged expenses associated with properties owned by Dixie Holdings or Dixie Developers because the parties had a â€œcourse of dealing of determining expenses prior to property sales and paying authorized expenses from the sale proceeds.â€Â  The master found HCH was entitled to receive one-half of the proceeds from the sale of 15 Felix Street, plus prejudgment interest on its half of the proceeds at the rate of 8.75% from the closing date of 15 Felix Street until the entry of judgment.Â  Finally, the master awarded HCH attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to section 33-44-1104 of the South Carolina Code â€œbased upon the record, the Affidavit of Counsel, and the factors applying to an award of fees and costs . . . .â€Â  
The master directed Mallon to turn over the proceeds from 15 Felix Street to HCHâ€™s counsel to be disbursed to HCH thirty days after the entry of his order.Â  The master also authorized HCH to deliver articles of termination pursuant to section 33-44-805 of the South Carolina Code to the Secretary of State for filing.Â  No post-trial motions were filed, and this appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In the underlying action, HCH sued in a derivative capacity for an accounting and injunctive relief.Â  Actions for an accounting, for an injunction, and shareholder derivative actions are all actions in equity.Â  See Lee v. Lee, 251 S.C. 533, 536, 164 S.E.2d 308, 309 (1968) (holding an action against a guardian ad litem for misappropriated funds was essentially an action for an accounting which was equitable in nature); Wiedemann v. Town of Hilton Head, 344 S.C. 233, 236, 542 S.E.2d 752, 753 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œActions for injunctive relief are equitable in nature.â€); Anthony v. Padmar, 320 S.C. 436, 445, 465 S.E.2d 745, 750 (Ct. App. 1995) (noting that derivative actions are equitable).Â  In an action in equity referred to a master for final judgment, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â 
Van Blarcum v. City of N. Myrtle Beach,
337 S.C. 446, 450, 523 S.E.2d 486, 488 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, we should not ignore the findings of the trial judge, who had the opportunity to hear and observe the witnesses.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Accounting
Mallon argues the master erred in refusing to order an accounting because one was necessary prior to the dissolution of Dixie Holdings.[7]Â  We agree.Â  
The Uniform Limited Liability Company Act outlines certain procedures for actions brought by members of a limited liability company.Â  Section 33-44-410 allows a member to maintain an action against the limited liability company or another member â€œfor legal or equitable relief, with or without an accountingâ€ to enforce, in pertinent part:

(1) the memberâ€™s rights under the operating agreement;
(2) the memberâ€™s rights under this chapter; and
(3) the rights that otherwise protect the interests of the member, including rights and interests arising independently of the memberâ€™s relationship to the company.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-410 (a) (Supp. 2004).Â  Certain events may cause the dissolution and winding up of a limited liability company, including where a member has applied for dissolution and there is a judicial decree to the effect that:

(a) the economic purpose of the company is likely to be unreasonably frustrated;
(b) another member has engaged in conduct relating to the companyâ€™s business that makes it not reasonably practicable to carry on the companyâ€™s business with that member;
(c) it is not otherwise reasonably practicable to carry on the companyâ€™s business in conformity with the articles of organization and the operating agreement;
(d) the company failed to purchase the petitionerâ€™s distributional interest after giving effect to provisions of the operating agreement modifying or superseding the provisions of Section 33-77-701; or
(e) the managers or members in control of the company have acted, are acting, or will act in a manner that is unlawful, oppressive, fraudulent, or unfairly prejudicial to the petitioner;
Â . . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-801(4) (Supp. 2004).Â  In winding up the business of the limited liability company, the assets of the company must be applied to â€œdischarge its obligations to creditors, including members who are creditors,â€ with the surplus being paid to members in accordance with their right to distribution.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-806(a) (Supp. 2004).
Members of limited liability companies may enter into an operating agreement that outlines the procedures governing the affairs of the company.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-103 (Supp. 2004).Â  Operating agreements are binding contracts that are superior to statutory authority where they are in place.Â  However, to the extent that the operating agreement is silent as to some matter, statutory law will apply.Â  Id.Â  Thus, courts deciding a controversy between members must first evaluate a limited liability companyâ€™s operating agreement regarding a particular procedure prior to supplementing any areas not covered by the agreement with statutory law.Â Â  
The sections of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ operating agreement pertinent to this discussion concern Mallonâ€™s claim for reimbursement and the need for an accounting.Â  Section 6.4 of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ operating agreement provided that the company â€œshall reimburse Members for all authorized, direct out-of-pocket expenses incurred on behalf of the Company.â€Â  In addition, the operating agreement contained the following provisions:Â  
Section 12.4 Priority of Distribution of Assets.Â  In the event of a Termination Event and the Members do not elect to continue the business of the Company, the assets of the Company shall be distributed in the following order and priority: 

(a)  To the payment of debts and liabilities of the Company (other than the Capital Contributions of the Members) and expenses of liquidation; 
(b)  To the setting up any reserves . . . ; and
(c)  To each Member in accordance with their respective Membership Percentages. 
. . . .
Section 12.6 Final Accounting.Â  Each of the Members shall be furnished with a statement setting forth the assets and liabilities of the Company as of the date of the complete liquidation.Â  Upon compliance by the Company with the foregoing distribution plan, the Members shall cease to be such, and they shall execute and cause to be filed any and all documents necessary with respect to termination and cancellation. 

Relying upon sections 33-44-410 and 33-44-801 of the South Carolina Code, the master noted that he had discretion to fashion a remedy short of an accounting.Â  The master concluded that Mallon, Dixie Holdings, and Dixie Developers failed to timely request an accounting and thus waived any right to have one.Â  Therefore, the master determined that awarding HCH 50% of the original proceeds from the sale of 15 Felix Street and dissolving Dixie Holdings was the appropriate remedy.Â  Although we recognize the master may grant relief to a member pursuant to section 33-44-410 without an accounting of the limited liability companyâ€™s business and the master has authority to order dissolution of a limited liability company pursuant to section 33-44-801, we find under these circumstances an accounting was necessary for the dissolution and winding up of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ business. 
Dixie Holdingsâ€™ operating agreement required an accounting prior to dissolution.Â  In order for the master to determine what amounts are to be distributed to the members pursuant to section 12.4 of the operating agreement, he was first required to determine what assets Dixie Holdings owned at the time of dissolution.Â  Those assets cannot be determined until the debts and liabilities of the company are paid.Â  Thus, the master must first conduct an accounting to determine the balance of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ assets after the payment of liabilities, which presumably under the operating agreement includes reimbursements to members.Â  In addition, section 12.6 of the operating agreement contemplates a final accounting upon complete liquidation.Â  Although Coker gave Mallon a box containing some of the companyâ€™s financial records in 2000, that act did not amount to a formal accounting necessary for the dissolution of the company.Â  Because the operating agreement required an accounting, the master erred in ignoring this document.Â  
Further, even assuming the operating agreement was silent as to some aspect of winding up Dixie Holdings, we find an accounting was warranted pursuant to statute.Â  Section 33-44-410 provides that a member can sue the limited liability company or another member to enforce rights under the operating agreement and relief may include an accounting.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-410 (Supp. 2004).Â  In winding up the business of a limited liability company, courts are required to determine the assets, discharge obligations to creditors, and distribute the surplus to members.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-806(a) (Supp. 2004).Â  In most instances, including the present case, this task can only be accomplished after an accounting.Â  Accordingly, the master erred in ordering the dissolution and ultimately the distribution of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ assets without first requiring an accounting.
In addition to finding an accounting necessary under these circumstances, we find Mallon did not waive his right to an accounting. 

A waiver is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or relinquishment of a known right.Â  Generally, the party claiming waiver must show that the party against whom waiver is asserted possessed, at the time, actual or constructive knowledge of his rights or of all the material facts upon which they depended.Â  

Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horizontal Prop. Regime,
307 S.C. 339, 344, 415 S.E.2d 384, 387-88 (1992). 
HCH pled its right to an accounting in its complaint, to which Mallon assented in his answer.[8]Â  In response to HCHâ€™s motion for a directed verdict, Mallon argued that an accounting should be performed.Â  The record is void of any evidence of Mallonâ€™s voluntary and intentional abandonment of his right to an accounting.Â  Thus, the master erred in finding Mallon waived his right to an accounting and in not conducting an accounting pursuant to the dissolution and winding up of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ business.Â  
Finally, HCH argues that no accounting was necessary because there were no debts after the master determined that Mallon had waived his right to setoff charges and the only asset to be distributed was the disputed $41,845.30.Â  This argument overlooks the fact that the parties were required by the operating agreement to have an accounting of all of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ business prior to dissolution.Â  The masterâ€™s findings that Mallon was not entitled to setoff and the fact that Dixie Holdingsâ€™ only remaining asset was the disputed amount will only serve to make this task easier. 
Accordingly, we reverse the masterâ€™s decision to deny the parties an accounting and remand this matter for a formal accounting of Dixie Holdings.Â  Our decision to remand this matter for an accounting affects other aspects of the masterâ€™s award to HCH.Â  Because the proceeds from the sale of 15 Felix Street are the property of Dixie Holdings until a final accounting is performed, we must also reverse the masterâ€™s decision to award one-half of the proceeds to HCH.Â  Further, because we reverse the award to HCH, we must likewise reverse the associated award of prejudgment interest.Â  The proceeds from the sale of 15 Felix Street shall be held in an escrow account for the benefit of Dixie Holdings until a final accounting is performed and the appropriate amounts distributed accordingly.[9]Â  
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs
Mallon argues the master erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to HCH.Â  Mallon contends because HCH asserted its own rights and not those of Dixie Holdings, HCHâ€™s action is not a derivative action.Â  Mallon also argues the attorney fee affidavit provided by counsel for HCH was not sufficient.Â  In addition, Mallon contends the master erred in not making specific findings required to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Finally, Mallon argues Coker created the necessity for the action because he failed to provide a proper accounting.
We find most of Mallonâ€™s arguments not preserved for our review.Â  In order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, with few exceptions, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.Â 
Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).Â  When a trial court fails to address the specific argument raised by the appellant, the appellant must make a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to obtain a ruling on the argument.Â  In the absence of such a motion, the matter is not preserved and the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal.Â 
Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991).Â  In addition, when raising an issue through an objection, the â€œobjection must be sufficiently specific to inform the trial court of the point being urged by the objector.â€Â 
Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).
HCH asserted in its complaint its entitlement to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to section 33-44-1104 of the South Carolina Code.Â  This section provides: 

If a derivative action for a limited liability company is successful, in whole or in part, or if anything is received by the plaintiff as a result of a judgment, compromise, or settlement of an action or claim, the court may award the plaintiff reasonable expenses, including reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees, and shall direct the plaintiff to remit to the limited liability company the remainder of the proceeds received.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-44-1104 (Supp. 2004).Â  At trial, counsel for HCH submitted an attorney fee affidavit into evidence arguing HCHâ€™s entitlement to these fees pursuant to section 33-44-1104.Â  Mallonâ€™s counsel responded with the following: â€œI do not concede, the Defendant does not concede that his client is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees in this case.Â  I donâ€™t take issue with the number of hours that he proposed, or the usual things, the amount of the hours he worked, attorney time, assistant time . . . .â€Â  However, Mallonâ€™s counsel did not further specify the reason for his objection, other than the following statement: â€œMr. Cokerâ€™s hand is so heavy in causing this problem to come about, that being equitable, you would find that my client, according to the facts in the record, that each party pays their own attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  
Therefore, we find Mallonâ€™s argument that HCHâ€™s action did not meet the requirements for a derivative action not preserved for our review.Â  Additionally, Mallonâ€™s counsel specifically conceded to the sufficiency of the attorney fee affidavit and, therefore, cannot take issue with it on appeal.Â  See 
TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 617, 503 S.E.2d 471, 474 (1998) (â€œAn issue conceded in a lower court may not be argued on appeal.â€).
In regard to Mallonâ€™s assertion that the master did not make sufficient findings with regard to his award of attorneyâ€™s fees, we find this argument not preserved for our review and, in addition, it is without merit.Â  
When a trial court makes a general ruling on an issue, but does not address the specific argument raised by the appellant and the appellant does not make a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to obtain a ruling on the argument, the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal.Â 
Noisette, 304 S.C. at 58, 403 S.E.2d at 124.
The master, in his order, stated:Â  â€œbased upon the record, the Affidavit of Counsel, and the factors applying to an award of fees and costs, that the Plaintiff is entitled to an award and that the total amount, $15,643[.]60, is reasonable.â€Â  Mallon, however, did not file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to alter or amend the masterâ€™s order.Â  Rather, Mallon argues the insufficiency of the masterâ€™s findings for the first time on appeal.Â  Therefore, we find this argument not preserved for our review.
Finally, Mallon alleges Coker failed to turn over the books and records, which he claims precipitated this litigation.Â  Thus, he argues it was inequitable for the master to award HCH attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
An award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.Â 
Wooten v. Wooten, 358 S.C. 54, 65, 594 S.E.2d 854, 860 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Although Mallon points to Cokerâ€™s failure to provide adequate company records as the catalyst to the underlying lawsuit, it is undisputed that HCH filed the lawsuit after repeated requests for Mallon to place Dixie Holdingsâ€™ funds from the sale of 15 Felix Street into a proper escrow account.Â  The master found Mallonâ€™s actions necessitated the lawsuit and awarded HCH attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We find the master did not abuse his discretion in awarding HCH attorneyâ€™s fees. 
CONCLUSION
We find Mallonâ€™s arguments supporting his contention that he is entitled to reimbursement for expenses paid on behalf of Dixie Holdings and Dixie Developers are either not preserved for our review or are without merit.Â  Therefore, we affirm the masterâ€™s order concerning these expenses.Â  In addition, we find the master erred in not conducting an accounting pursuant to dissolving and winding up the business of Dixie Holdings.Â  We order the proceeds from the sale of 15 Felix Street to be placed in an escrow account for the benefit of Dixie Holdings.Â  Because we find the master erred in not conducting an accounting, he further erred in making a final distribution to HCH from the proceeds of the sale of 15 Felix Street.Â  Additionally, because we find the award to HCH in error, we find no award upon which to grant HCH prejudgment interest.Â  Finally, we find no error by the master in awarding HCH attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the masterâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]At some point prior to this action, Mallon and HCH bought Storenâ€™s interest in Dixie Holdings and Storen filed a Statement of Dissociation with the South Carolina Secretary of Stateâ€™s Office.Â  He was not a party to the underlying action and is not a party in this appeal.
[2] From the record, it appears Cynthia Coker did not take an active role in HCH or Dixie Holdings.Â  
[3]Â  Coker also performed financial duties for Dixie Developers until the company was sold to Mallon.Â  In fact, both Dixie Holdings and Dixie Developers utilized one banking account under the name of Dixie Developers.Â  
[4]Â  Although both Mallon and Coker had signatory authority on the Dixie Developers bank account for both Dixie Holdings and Dixie Developers, Mallon opened a new account in the name of Dixie Developers for which he had sole signatory authority.Â  Further, at the time Mallon opened the new account, he was the sole member of Dixie Developers.Â  
[5]Â  Neither Dixie Holdings nor Dixie Developers is a party to this appeal.Â  
[6]Â  Dixie Holdingsâ€™ fourth and final property was sold in December 2001 and the proceeds were split equally.Â  Thus, Dixie Holdings no longer owns any property.Â  
[7]Â  Mallon also asserts the master erred in limiting the scope of the underlying action to the 15 Felix Street property.Â  However, the substance of the argument in support of the first issue on appeal fails to address why the master erred in limiting the scope of the action to 15 Felix Street.Â  In addition, Mallon fails to cite any supporting authority for his position.Â  Therefore, Mallon abandoned this argument on appeal and we need not address it.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (noting that where a party fails to city any supporting authority or where the argument is merely a conclusory statement, the issue is deemed abandoned on appeal).
[8]Â  Mallonâ€™s letter to the clerk of court, treated as his initial answer by the master, stated that there was a need for a full accounting and he desired arbitration.Â  In his formal answer later filed after obtaining counsel, Mallon initially states that he believes an accounting is appropriate for both parties.Â  Later in the formal answer, he alleges that HCH should be estopped from requesting an accounting from Mallon, Dixie Holdings, and Dixie Developers because Cokerâ€™s failure to maintain financial records rendered an accounting from them impossible.Â  Although HCH argues that the latter statement amounted to a wavier of the request for an accounting, we interpret it as merely an expression that Cokerâ€™s mismanagement of financial records frustrated the partiesâ€™ ability to conduct an accounting.Â  Thus, these sections can be consistently read together to indicate that Mallon still desired an accounting.
[9]Â  Mallon raises several other issues on appeal, including whether the circuit court erred in:Â  (1) disallowing Mallonâ€™s charges for the Felix Street properties; (2) disallowing the charges involved with the Dixie Developers properties; (3) finding the relief granted was justified by Mallonâ€™s attempt to dissociate from Dixie Holdings; (4) excluding evidence of Cokerâ€™s self-dealing and misappropriation of Dixie Holdingsâ€™ funds; and (5) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The arguments in support of these issues, for the most part, either were not raised below or were presented in Mallonâ€™s brief in a conclusory manner without supporting authority.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court my not be considered on appeal); Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding that failure to provide argument or supporting authority for an issue renders it abandoned).Â  Thus, these issues each have procedural problems that foreclose appellate review and we decline to address them.Â  However, we address the attorneyâ€™s fees issue to the extent it may be viewed as preserved.

title: Waters v. Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance Company
description: This case involves the construction of a life insurance policy, particularly the insured's right to change the benificiary when the insured does expressly reserve the right in the appication.
text:
Waters v. Southern Farm Bureau, 13463


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ray Allen Waters, Appellant,
v.
Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance Company and Mitchell Harvey
Bridwell, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4005
Heard May 11, 2005 â€“ Filed June 27, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
William H. Ehlies, II, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Ronald S. Clement, Samuel W. Outten, and Jennifer S. Barr, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Ray Allen Waters appeals a circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance Company and Mitchell Harvey Bridwell.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
In 1986, Appellant phoned Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance Company (â€œSouthern Farmâ€) to establish an insurance policy on the life of his wife, Brenda Waters.Â  An agent of Southern Farm visited the Watersâ€™ home and conducted an interview of Appellant and his wife.Â  During the course of the interview, the agent filled out the required application form on behalf of the couple.Â  Brenda Waters was designated in the application as the owner and insured of the policy and Appellant as its sole beneficiary.Â  The application contained the following statement, prompting the applicant to mark one of two boxes:Â  â€œOwner ٱ does / ٱ does not reserve the right to change the Beneficiary.â€Â Â  Neither box was marked on the application form. The agent submitted the application to Southern Farm and the life insurance policy was later issued.Â  The policy incorporated the application as part of the contract for insurance.
In 1999, Appellant and Brenda Waters separated.Â  Mrs. Waters, who was then suffering from brain cancer, moved in with her mother.Â  In July 1999, she submitted a â€œChange of Beneficiaryâ€ form to Southern Farm designating her brother, Richard Bridwell, as the new beneficiary.Â  In February 2000, Mrs. Waters submitted another â€œChange of Beneficiaryâ€ form amending the policy to designate Mitchell Bridwell, another brother, as the sole beneficiary.Â  Southern Farm complied with both requests, as confirmed by two change of beneficiary notices sent to Mrs. Waters.
In October 2000, Brenda Waters passed away.Â  Appellant attempted to collect on the Southern Farm life insurance policy, but the proceeds were paid to Mitchell Bridwell in accordance with the last change of beneficiary request.Â  Appellant brought suit, arguing the insurance contract was breached by denying a non-revocable beneficiary the proceeds of the policy.Â  The circuit court granted Southern Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment, concluding that the undisputed evidence reflected the partiesâ€™ intent that the owner could change the beneficiary and that Mrs. Waters had not waived her right to do so.Â  After Appellantâ€™s motion to alter or amend the circuit courtâ€™s order was denied, the present appeal was filed.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  
In determining whether a triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth., 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).Â  Even if there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 415, 401 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1991).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Appellant argues the circuit court erred in granting Southern Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment because the ownerâ€™s failure to declare her intention on the application regarding the right to change the beneficiary gives rise to an ambiguity in the insurance contract. We agree.[1]
When an insurance policy does not reserve to the insured the right to change the beneficiary, â€œthe beneficiary, upon the issuance of the policy, acquires a vested interest in the proceeds of the insurance when available according to the terms of the policy, which cannot be divested by any act of the insured.â€Â  Antley v. New York Life Ins. Co., 139 S.C. 23, 27, 137 S.E. 199, 200 (1927).Â  Of course an insured may expressly reserve the right to change the beneficiary, as was clearly contemplated by the ignored prompt in the application of the present case.Â  The right to change the beneficiary, however, may also be reserved by the language of the policy itself.Â  See Bost v. Volunteer State Life Ins. Co., 114 S.C. 405, 409, 103 S.E. 771, 772 (1920).Â  Because the owner failed to expressly indicate her intention to reserve or not to reserve this right in the present case, we look to the language of the policy for guidance.
The insurance policy in question addresses the right to change the beneficiary in three instances, two of which seem to reserve the right of the insured to change the beneficiary and one which seems to require that the right be expressly reserved upon application.Â  The schedule page of the policy defines the beneficiary as the person â€œnamed in the application, unless changed by owner.â€ (Emphasis added).Â  Section 7.1 of the policy, which contains the heading â€œBENEFICIARY,â€ likewise states â€œ[t]he Primary and Contingent Beneficiary are as named in the application, unless changed by the owner.â€ (Emphasis added).Â  Section 7.3, however, states, â€œ[i]f the right to change the Beneficiary has been reserved, the owner may change the Beneficiary during the Insuredâ€™s lifetime by filing written notice to the Company.â€ (Emphasis added).Â  Consequently, we find ambiguity in the language of the insurance contract.Â  While Section 7.3 seems to require an express reservation on the part of the applicant, Southern Farm promptly granted both of Mrs. Watersâ€™ requests to change the policyâ€™s beneficiary, further confounding the partiesâ€™ intent regarding this issue. 
â€œWhere there is ambiguity, uncertainty or doubt as to proper construction of [an insurance] contract, intention of the parties becomes a question of fact for the jury to determine.â€Â  Garrett v. Pilot Life Ins. Co., 241 S.C. 299, 305, 128 S.E.2d 171, 174 (1962).Â  After a consideration of extrinsic evidence, the jury is to resolve all remaining ambiguity in favor of the insured, in this case, the late Brenda Waters.Â  Id. at 304-305, 128 S.E.2d at 174.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment is
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 ANDERSON and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

[1] Appellant first argues we should reverse the circuit court and rule in his favor as a matter of law.Â  For the reasons set forth in this opinion, we instead find an issue of fact for determination by a jury.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Brandon Pinkard, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4006
Submitted May 1, 2005 â€“ Filed June 27, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this criminal appeal, we are asked to decide whether a defendant forfeits his right to make the final closing argument to the jury when he offers only non-testimonial evidence.Â  Brandon Pinkard was convicted of voluntary manslaughter.Â  On appeal, Pinkard claims error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling that his proposed display of a tattoo to the jury would constitute evidence, thereby depriving him of the right to make the last argument.Â  We affirm and hold the presentation of any evidence by a defendantâ€”whether characterized as testimonial or non-testimonialâ€”forfeits his right to make the last argument to the jury. 
FACTS
On June 7, 2000, during a fight outside an apartment complex between Pinkard and a third party, Roger Keitt intervened in an effort to ease tensions between the combatants.Â  According to witnesses, Pinkard responded by shooting and killing Keitt.Â  Pinkard was indicted for murder, convicted of voluntary manslaughter by a jury, and sentenced to 24 years imprisonment.Â  During trial, several witnesses identified Pinkard as the shooter, but none mentioned Pinkard as having a tattoo.Â  
Near the trialâ€™s conclusion, Pinkard asked the trial court if he could show the jury a tattoo on his arm without forfeiting the right to make the final argument.Â  The trial court held that such a display of the tattoo would constitute the introduction of evidence and would thus preclude Pinkard from having the last argument.Â  Pinkard chose not to exhibit his tattoo to the jury in order to preserve his right to the final closing argument.Â  Pinkard appeals, claiming the trial court erred in ruling the display to the jury would constitute the introduction of evidence.
LAW/ANALYSIS
When a defendant in a criminal case offers no evidence, he is entitled to the final closing argument to the jury.Â  State v. Rodgers, 269 S.C. 22, 24, 235 S.E.2d 808, 809 (1977) (citing State v. Gellis, 158 S.C. 471, 487, 155 S.E. 849, 855 (1930)).Â  â€œThe right to open and close the argument to the jury is a substantial right, the denial of which is reversible error.â€Â  Rodgers, 269 S.C. at 24-25, 235 S.E.2d at 809. 
While the display of physical characteristics, such as a tattoo, is non-testimonial,[1] it remains evidence.Â  See State v. Hart, 306 S.C. 344, 346, 412 S.E.2d 380, 381 (1991) (stating that exhibition of a defendantâ€™s physical characteristics is treated â€œlike any other evidenceâ€); 2 McCormick on Evidence Â§ 215 (5th ed. 1999) (noting that â€œ[t]he physical characteristics of a person may . . . constitute relevant evidence in a criminal prosecutionâ€) (emphasis added).Â  The trial court correctly ruled that the proposed display by Pinkard of his tattoo would have been evidence, albeit non-testimonial.Â  Accordingly, Pinkard was not entitled to display his tattoo to the jury and retain the right to the final closing argument. See Gellis, 158 S.C. at 487, 155 S.E. at 855 (1930) (holding that the state retains the right to the final closing â€œif a defendant offers any evidence on trial of the caseâ€); cf. State v. Mouzon, 326 S.C. 199, 203-04, 485 S.E.2d 918, 920-21 (1997) (noting that a jury view of the crime scene pursuant to South Carolina Code section 14-7-1320 â€œis not regarded as evidenceâ€ and that defendant was therefore â€œentitled to the last closing argumentâ€).
AFFIRMED. 
 GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

[1] â€œTestimonyâ€ is not synonymous with â€œevidenceâ€; the latter is a more comprehensive term.Â  Evidence is said to be testimonial when â€œelicited from a witness in contrast to documentary evidence or real evidence.â€ Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1476 (6th ed. 1990); see also Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757, 763-64 (1966) (distinguishing between testimonial and non-testimonial evidence); 29A Am. Jur. 2d Evidence Â§ 951 (1994) (noting that â€œthe accused, while not a witness on his behalf, may be required to display to the trier of fact wounds . . . tattoos . . . or other distinguishing features.Â  Because such an exhibit is not testimonial in nature, the defendant is not required to take the stand before being allowed to exhibit himself to the jury . . .â€).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Deral L. Stanley, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4007
Heard June 15, 2005 â€“ Filed June 27, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
  J.M. Long, III, of Conway, for Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor J. Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.

    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â Deral L. Stanley (Deral) appeals from his conviction for trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  Deral argues: (1) he was prejudiced when the trial court ordered the imprisonment of a witness who contradicted his prior statement to the police on the witness stand, and then later allowed the witness to return to testify; and (2) the trial court erred by failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the night of June 12, 2003, Officer Will Lynch, a traffic officer for the City of North Myrtle Beach, was operating a radar detector on Possum Trot Road.Â  He determined that an oncoming vehicle was traveling approximately twelve miles per hour over the posted speed limit.Â  Officer Lynch, who was on a motorcycle, began to follow the vehicle and activated his blue lights.Â  A high-speed chase ensued.Â  Officer Lynch observed two people in the fleeing vehicle.Â  The driver of the vehicle attempted to pass another car, but instead he struck the median, â€œspun out,â€ and came to a stop without hitting any other vehicles.
As Officer Lynch approached, the driver exited the disabled vehicle and ran across the street into the parking lot of a nearby miniature golf course.Â  The passenger in the vehicle was Deral Stanley.Â  When Officer Lynch pulled up to the scene of the accident, Deral exited the vehicle and began to walk away.Â  Officer Lynch immediately ordered Deral to get on the ground, handcuffed Deral, and arrested him.
Officer Lynch rolled Deral over to check him for weapons.Â  At that time, he â€œnoticed down on the ground where [Deral] was laying a large bag of what appeared to . . . be crack cocaine.â€Â  Officer Lynch declared: â€œWhen I rolled him over, basically, they were right in the areaâ€”I guess you would say if I was to roll him back down, basically, around his belly button area.â€Â  Officer Lynch retrieved the bag, which SLED later determined contained 22.63 grams of crack cocaine.Â  When Officer Lynch patted Deral down, he found $4,220 in cash in his pockets.Â  An inventory search of the vehicle revealed other drug paraphernaliaâ€”plastic baggies and digital scalesâ€”on the passenger-side floorboard.
The driver of the vehicle was Richard Stanley (Richard), Deralâ€™s cousin.Â  Richard was apprehended soon afterward.Â  He was cited for speeding and charged with failure to stop for a blue light and driving without a license.
When he arrived at the police station, Richard waived his rights and gave a statement to Officer Mandy Little.Â  Officer Little wrote down what Richard said and then he signed it at the bottom.Â  The substance of the statement was that Richard was driving Deral to â€œsell somebody somethingâ€ when they â€œsaw blue lights.â€Â  According to Richard, Deral instructed him â€œto go,â€ and Richard â€œwent because he got scared and had no license.â€
At trial, the State called Richard.Â  When the State asked Richard if his signature was on his statement, he hesitated.Â  The trial judge sent the jury out and asked whether the statement had been made under oath.Â  The State asserted the statement was made under oath, although defense counsel disagreed.[1]Â  The trial judge then warned Richard that if his trial testimony differed substantially from his prior statement he could be indicted for perjury.
When the jury returned, Richard admitted his signature was on the statement.Â  However, he denied any prior mention of selling something, claiming â€œI ainâ€™t said nothing about going to sell nothing.â€Â  He further denied telling Officer Little that the drugs belonged to Deral.Â  In fact, Richard stated the drugs belonged to him, not Deral.Â  Richard testified he gave the money to Deral during the car chase.Â  He said the baggies and scales were on the center console, but had fallen onto the passenger side floorboard during the accident.Â  Richard declared he threw the bag of drugs when he exited the car, and Deral must have accidentally fallen on it when he was arrested.Â  After his testimony, the trial judge asked Richard to remain in the courtroom because he might be subject to recall.
After the judge dismissed the jury for the afternoon, he called Richard forward and the following colloquy occurred:

THE COURT:Â  Under oath you just testified that you are guilty in trafficking in cocaine.Â  You said that under oath. 
MR. RICHARD STANLEY:Â  Yes, sir. 
THE COURT:Â  Arrest this individual.Â  Put him in jail.Â  Leave him there.Â  Heâ€™s either guilty by his own admission in trafficking in cocaine or heâ€™s guilty of perjury. 
Heâ€™s to go to jail.Â  Have him indicted first thing in the morning. 
I will not permit that sort of conduct in my courtroom. 
Now, heâ€™s, obviously, either guilty of trafficking in cocaine or heâ€™s lying. 
You agree with that, [Defense Counsel].Â  He canâ€™t have it both ways.
MR. LONG:Â  Thatâ€™s correct, Your Honor. 
THE COURT:Â  Alright.
He will remain in jail. 
Let the record reflect that Iâ€™m also putting him in jail tonight in the event we will need him for further testimony in the morning.Â  He may be subject to recall, being under that I want to make sure heâ€™s here for recall by either the State or the defendant.
But I want him indicted in the morning. 

The following morning, the judge appointed the Senior Public Defender to act as counsel for Richard and asked her to speak with him along with the Solicitor.Â  Richard was not served with a warrant at that time.Â  Richard was then brought into the courtroom and charged as follows:

THE COURT:Â  They [are] going to put you back on the stand under oath and all the Court wants from youâ€”Iâ€™mÂ Â  not interested in who you help or hurt.Â  All Iâ€™m interested in is you tell us the truth and the absolute truth and nothing but the truth.Â  Do you understand that?

Richard responded, â€œYes, sir.â€Â  Richard then recanted his earlier testimony.Â  Richard professed that the drugs belonged to Deral and that Deral was going to sell them.Â  On cross-examination, defense counsel elicited testimony that Richard had been â€œlocked upâ€ the night before and threatened with service of warrants for trafficking in cocaine and perjury.
After the State rested, defense counsel moved for a directed verdict of not guilty.Â  Additionally, defense counsel moved for a mistrial based on the trial judgeâ€™s handling of Richardâ€™s testimony.Â  The judge denied both motions.
Deral testified in his own defense.Â  Deral claimed Richard was driving because he had been drinking.Â  Deral stated Richard gave him the money during the car chase.Â  He denied possessing the drugs, vowing â€œI didnâ€™t have no drugs on me.â€Â  On cross-examination, Deral admitted having conversations with Richard in which he learned that Richard would â€œtake the blameâ€ for the drug charge.
At the close of the evidence, defense counsel renewed his motions for a directed verdict and a mistrial.Â  Both motions were again denied.Â  The jury found Deral guilty of trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  Because Deral had two prior convictions, he received the mandatory minimum sentence of twenty-five years.Â  Defense counsel made post-trial motions for a mistrial, a new trial, and judgment notwithstanding the verdict, which the judge denied.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Motion for Mistrial
Deral argues the trial judgeâ€™s handling of Richardâ€™s testimony was erroneous.Â  Deral alleges prejudice in that the trial judgeâ€™s conduct amounted to intimidation of a witness.Â  He claims the judge should have granted his motion for a mistrial.Â  We disagree.
A.Â  Issue Preservation
Initially, we note this issue may not have been properly preserved.Â  Although defense counsel moved for a mistrial after the State rested, no contemporaneous objection was made.Â  Instead, when the trial judge ordered Richard sent to jail, he stated: â€œYou agree with that, Mr. Long.Â  He canâ€™t have it both ways.â€Â  Deralâ€™s attorney replied: â€œThatâ€™s correct, Your Honor.â€Â  Our courts have held a failure to contemporaneously object to the introduction of evidence claimed to be prejudicial cannot be later bootstrapped by a motion for a mistrial.Â  State v. Lynn, 277 S.C. 222, 284 S.E.2d 786 (1981); State v. Moultrie, 316 S.C. 547, 451 S.E.2d 34 (Ct. App. 1994); State v. Wilkins, 310 S.C. 81, 425 S.E.2d 68 (Ct. App. 1992); see also State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004) (contemporaneous objection required to preserve error for appellate review); State v. Atchison, 268 S.C. 588, 235 S.E.2d 294 (1977) (noting that if a party fails to make a proper contemporaneous objection to the admission of evidence, he cannot later raise the issue by a motion for mistrial); State v. Crosby, 348 S.C. 387, 398-399, 559 S.E.2d 352, 358-59 (Ct. App. 2001), revâ€™d on other grounds, 355 S.C. 47, 584 S.E.2d 110 (2003) (holding that no issue is preserved for appellate review if the objecting party accepts the judgeâ€™s ruling and does not contemporaneously make an additional objection to sufficiency of the curative charge or move for a mistrial).
B.Â  Mistrial
In any event, even if preserved, we find the issue to be without merit.
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the trial judge. Â State v. Vazquez, Op. No. 25975 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed April 25, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 18 at 43); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 575 S.E.2d 77 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The courtâ€™s decision will not be overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 530 S.E.2d 626 (2000); State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998); see also State v. Arnold, 266 S.C. 153, 157, 221 S.E.2d 867, 868 (1976) (noting the general rule of this State is that â€œthe ordering of, or refusal of a motion for mistrial is within the discretion of the trial judge and such discretion will not be overturned in the absence of abuse thereof amounting to an error of law.â€).
â€œâ€˜The power of a court to declare a mistrial ought to be used with the greatest caution under urgent circumstances, and for very plain and obvious causesâ€™ stated into the record by the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 354, 573 S.E.2d 856, 862 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting State v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 236 S.E.2d 33 (1977)); see also State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating mistrial should only be granted in cases of manifest necessity and with the greatest caution for very plain and obvious reasons).Â  The granting of a motion for a mistrial is an extreme measure which should be taken only where an incident is so grievous that prejudicial effect can be removed in no other way.Â  State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999); Adams, 354 S.C. at 377, 580 S.E.2d at 793.
A mistrial should only be granted when â€œabsolutely necessary,â€ and a defendant must show both error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.Â  Harris, 340 S.C. at 63, 530 S.E.2d at 628; Simmons, 352 S.C. at 354, 573 S.E.2d at 862; see also State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) (finding mistrial should not be granted unless absolutely necessary; to receive mistrial, defendant must show error and resulting prejudice).Â  â€œThe less than lucid test is therefore declared to be whether the mistrial was dictated by manifest necessity or the ends of public justice.â€Â  State v. Prince, 279 S.C. 30, 33, 301 S.E.2d 471, 472 (1983).Â  â€œWhether a mistrial is manifestly necessary is a fact specific inquiry.â€Â  State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 457, 539 S.E.2d 717, 719 (Ct. App. 2000).
C.Â  Section 16-9-10
Deral contends that Richardâ€™s testimony at trial was not perjury because the police statement was not made under oath.Â  We disagree.
Section 16-9-10 of the South Carolina Code provides in pertinent part:

(A)(1) It is unlawful for a person to wilfully give false, misleading, or incomplete testimony under oath in any court of record, judicial, administrative, or regulatory proceeding in this State.
(2) It is unlawful for a person to wilfully give false, misleading, or incomplete information on a document, record, report, or form required by the laws of this State.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-10 (2003).
â€œGiving false testimony at trial constitutes the felony of perjury and subjects the perjurer to a fine and/or up to five years imprisonment.â€Â  Collins v. Doe, 343 S.C. 119, 124, 539 S.E.2d 62, 64 (Ct. App. 2000), revâ€™d on other grounds, 352 S.C. 462, 574 S.E.2d 739 (2002).Â  Perjury or false swearing may constitute contempt of court.Â  See, e.g., Crute v. Crute, 70 S.E.2d 727 (Ga. Ct. App. 1952).
In the case sub judice, Richardâ€™s initial trial testimony directly contradicted his prior testimony given in a police statement.Â  Giving false information in a document or report required by the laws of this State is perjury.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-10(A)(2).Â  Thus, if the information given to Officer Little was false, Richard was guilty of perjury.Â  If the information was true, Richard perjured himself on the stand by contradicting it under subsection (A)(1).
D.Â  Arrest of Witness
Deral maintains he was prejudiced when Richard was arrested and sent to jail, and then later returned to reverse his prior testimony.Â  This assertion is meritless.
â€œIt is the duty of the court to exercise supervision and control over the witnesses in attendance at the trial.â€Â  23A C.J.S. Criminal Law Â§ 1191 (1989).Â  In South Carolina, it is firmly settled that the presiding judge has the right to order the arrest of a witness in open court who has made contradictory statements amounting to perjury.Â  The supreme court addressed this issue in State v. McKay, 89 S.C. 234, 71 S.E. 858 (1911):

When the witness Purvis came off the stand, the solicitor ordered the sheriff, in open court, to arrest him and take him to jail to answer an indictment for perjury.Â  This was done against defendantâ€™s protest.Â  It is alleged that this was prejudicial to defendant, because it was calculated to intimidate any other witness from varying the testimony which he had given at the preliminary investigation.Â  There is nothing in the record tending to show any such prejudice.Â  It is purely conjectural and barely possible, but highly improbable.Â  Therefore it affords no ground for reversal.Â  On the contrary, we are inclined to commend prompt action by those charged with the administration of the law, when it has been flagrantly violated; and we are of the opinion that if perjurers were more invariably and promptly and vigorously prosecuted and punished, there would be fewer miscarriages of justice in our courts.

Id. at 236, 71 S.E. at 859.Â  Thereafter, in State v. Campbell, 150 S.C. 449, 148 S.E. 472 (1929), the supreme court explained:

The second question is as to the right of the presiding judge to order the arrest of a witness in open court who, in the opinion of the trial judge, has made contradictory statements, which in fact amount to perjury.Â  This question has been settled against the appellant by the case of State v. McKay, 89 S.C. 234, 71 S.E. 858 [(1911)].Â  The trial judge is present in the atmosphere of the trial, and he must, in the administration of justice, uphold the dignity of the courts, and he would be derelict in his duty if he did not take such steps as he conceives it his duty to see that justice is administered in accordance with sound principles of law.Â  It might be said in passing that it does not appear in the case for appeal that the judge actually had the witness arrested, and under the rules of this court no exception can be considered which does not find substantiation in the printed case.

Id. at 450-51, 148 S.E. at 473; see also H.D. Warren, Annotation, Statements, Comments, or Conduct of Court or Counsel Regarding Perjury as Ground for New Trial or Reversal in Civil Action or Criminal Prosecution Other Than for Perjury, 127 A.L.R. 1385 (1940) (citing McKay and Campbell and noting that South Carolina courts have used language which seems to indicate the mere fact that a commitment for perjury is made or ordered is insufficient to establish prejudice or constitute reversible error, but indicating that such a result may be shown in a proper case).
In Graves v. State, 309 S.C. 307, 422 S.E.2d 125 (1992), our supreme court articulated:

Petitioner also alleges that the trial judgeâ€™s comments on credibility about a defense witness denied him an impartial jury and violated his due process rights.Â  Again, the PCR judge found this issue to be without merit.Â  At the PCR hearing, petitioner alleged that the trial judgeâ€™s threats of perjury to a witness prejudiced him.Â  Petitioner argues that the trial judgeâ€™s comments amounted to comments on the credibility of a witness.Â  During cross-examination, the trial judge reminded the witness: â€œYou are under oath subject to perjury.Â  I need to warn you, so you must answer the questions truthfully.â€Â  Further, he stated: â€œThe jury can hear. They can find out whether or not you are straightforward or not.Â  Those are matters for the jury.â€
Petitioner argues that this Court should adopt the holding of the North Carolina case of State v. Rhodes, 290 N.C. 16, 224 S.E.2d 631 (1976), where the court held that any intimation by the judge in the juryâ€™s presence that a witness had committed perjury would be reversible error.Â  Rhodes, however, is distinguishable from the present case.Â  In Rhodes, the trial judge made a long statement regarding the witnessâ€™ testimony and he clearly thought she had committed perjury.Â  In Rhodes, the North Carolina Supreme Court stated that a judge may caution a witness regarding perjury outside of the juryâ€™s presence.Â  However, the court cautioned that any intimation that a witness had committed perjury in the juryâ€™s presence is reversible error.
In Rhodes, the court set forth several reasons for its holding.Â  The court saw several dangers including the fact that a judge is unlikely to warn a witness about perjury unless he has determined that the witness has committed perjury which is a fact solely for the juryâ€™s determination.Â  Secondly, a witness may change his testimony after being threatened with perjury charges.Â  Third, a warning may discourage questioning the witness further.
As to whether the comments could be construed as a factual determination by the judge, the trial judge stated whether the witness committed perjury was for the jury to determine.Â  From a review of the testimony of the witness, the trial judgeâ€™s comments did not cause her to change her testimony or discourage further questions.
While these reasons set forth in Rhodes are valid, we decline to apply the holding to the present case.Â  Although the trial judge should have refrained from cautioning the witness regarding perjury in the presence of the jury, under the circumstances of this case, we do not think it is reversible error.Â  We find the trial judgeâ€™s comments do not amount to prejudice which denied petitioner an impartial jury or violated his due process rights.

Id. at 311-12, 422 S.E.2d at 127-28; see also State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 546, 514 S.E.2d 584, 587 (1999) (â€œ[T]here is generally no prejudice when the trial courtâ€™s hostile comments are made outside the juryâ€™s presence.â€).
All courts have inherent power to punish for contempt.Â  Curlee v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 287 S.E.2d 915 (1982); State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 611 S.E.2d 273 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  This power is essential to the preservation of order in judicial proceedings and the due administration of justice.Â  Id.Â  
The trial judge acted within his discretion to warn Richard and to take action to prevent the miscarriage of justice by his perjury.
E.Â  Other Jurisdictions
The South Carolina rule is in accord with that of other jurisdictions.Â  In State v. Sheffield, 228 P.2d 431 (N.M. 1951), the trial testimony of a Stateâ€™s witness contradicted earlier statements given to police officers.Â  The Supreme Court of New Mexico, citing State v. McKay and State v. Campbell, amplified:

It appears from the record that, during the progress of the trial, in the presence of the jury, and while Oscar Connally was on the stand testifying as a witness for the State, the court told the district attorney to â€œenter a contempt charge against this man for perjury and to deliver him to the custody of the sheriff.â€
The action of the court was within the power and sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  That it might have had a bad effect upon the jury, and thereby prejudiced the defendantâ€™s case, was a matter to be considered by the trial judge at the time he committed the witness to the custody of the sheriff, but we do no[t] think it was error to do so under the circumstances.Â  State v.
